My setup:

issue.title: Packaging should not include service level patterns
issue.body:
We have the following config which adds all python code also into the `warmUpPluginOfficeHoursWarmer.zip`. I tried various variations to exclude the files and the only thing that worked is setting `package.individually` to `true` or moving the package block into the function. Moving the package block into the function does not apply the patterns though and we will end up with a large zip file.

Imo `package.patterns` should not be joined to package the warmer function.

```yaml
functions:
  app:
    handler: wsgi_handler.handler
    timeout: 30
    layers:
      - Ref: PythonRequirementsLambdaLayer
    warmup:
      officeHoursWarmer:
        enabled: prod

package:
  individually: false
  patterns:
    - "!**"
    - "serverless_sdk*/**"
    - "app/**"
    - "module1/**"
    - "module2/**"
    - "module3/**"
    - "*.py"
```

What worked:
```yaml
functions:
  app:
    handler: wsgi_handler.handler
    timeout: 30
    layers:
      - Ref: PythonRequirementsLambdaLayer
    package:
      patterns:
        - "!**"
        - "serverless_sdk*/**"
        - "app/**"
        - "module1/**"
        - "module2/**"
        - "module3/**"
        - "*.py"
    warmup:
      officeHoursWarmer:
        enabled: prod

package:
  individually: true
```

issue.title: Path of .middleware folder when searching for modules is broken with default folderName in Serverless 3.0
issue.body:
The path of the .middleware folder using the default configuration is broken in serverless 3.0 + serverless-middleware 3.0.

```
Framework Core: 3.22.0 (local) 3.21.0 (global)
Plugin: 6.2.2
SDK: 4.3.2
```

Error: ``` Error: Cannot find module '/project-name/.build/.middleware/service-name-functionName'```

Serverless for some reason is assuming that the ```/.middleware/``` directory is located inside of ```/.build/.middleware/``` and that is not the default location of the folder.

The ```pathToRoot``` variable resolves to just ```..``` without a preceding slash, (```../```) and I thought that was the problem although manually altering the following did not fix it.  Although, it does print out the preceding slash in the logs and doesn't seem to hurt anything.  Not sure if *not* adding a preceding slash was intentional or not.

```const pathToRoot = path.relative(pathFolder, this.serviceDir);``` - original
```const pathToRoot = path.relative(pathFolder, this.serviceDir) + '/';``` - modified

If I find a fix, I'm happy to commit it but since you likely can pinpoint it faster, I'm posting this for visibility into the issue as well as for archival purposes.

If I find a fix, I'm happy to commit it but since you likely can pinpoint it faster, I'm posting this for visibility into the issue as well as for archival purposes.

issue.title: Lack of versioning on the dependencies causes trouble
issue.body: **Describe the bug** Lack of versioning on the dependencies: * makes downloads idempotent (2 downloads might not yield the same result) * makes imposible to run `npm audits` * doesn't let GitHub's dependabot automatically create a PR to update a version whenever a vulnerability is found This is a request to revert #1278 and reset specific versions in package.json and add a package-lock.json. I know that it adds a bit of a maintenance. But dependabot will take care of the crucial stuff, it's not so hard to every now and then do a general update of dependencies (in my own OSS packages I do so before cutting new releases) and it will provide great benefits. I'm happy to set all the latests versions and create the package-lock.json, and create a PR if it would be welcomed. **To Reproduce** Steps to reproduce the behavior on a MacBook with Node 18.0.0: 1. npm install 2. npm test **Expected behavior** The tests run successfully. Which only happens after manually reinstalling the latest Karma version. **Screenshots** When running `TEST_BROWSER_NAME=ChromeHeadless npm test` I get: When running `npm test` and opening the browser I get the same: **Client (please complete the following information):** - OS: MacOS - Browser: All browsers - Browser version: [e.g. 22] **Server (please complete the following information):** - noVNC version: latests - VNC server: not relevant - WebSocket proxy: not relevant

comment.body:
Hi guys,

I really don't think that keeping dependencies up-to-date is such a big effort.
It's a matter of having a recurring task to run
```sh
// See outdated dependencies
npm outdated
// Automatically update all minor/patch version
npm update
// Fix vulnerabilities updating minor/patch versions
npm audit fix
```

It could be put in a scheduled action or even I or some other contributor could put something in my calendar and do a PR once a month or so.

From my point of view, one of the main advantages of open-sourcing a project is that you get a bunch of eyes on the code and you benefit from the crowd to identify vulnerabilities, bugs, etc.
Leaving this to individual developers removes that benefit and forces each and every developer to play around with dependencies to get things to work (if something like my karma issue happens) and to lock dependencies and do a full round of testing to ensure that everything works and there are no vulnerabilities.

That said, I've tried to explain why I think that this is a good idea and an improvement to the project.
But at the end of the day, you guys are the owners.
So it's up to you...

issue.body:
This PR adds support for automatic copy-pasting.
So when you are focused on the canvas and paste text it's pasted in the server and when you copy something in the server it's automatically copied to your local keyboard.

I've seen #1301 and #1174. But this takes a very different approach since it adds support for copy-pasting to noVNC's core. And I think that it's quite cleaner.

I've tested it in Safari, Firefox, and Chrome.
Unfortunately, the Clipboard API is only supported by Chrome and the `paste` event is broken (see https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=634426).
So it just does nothing in Safari and Firefox, while in Chrome the copying of data works but not the pasting.

So, for now, this is not super useful but it should become better as browser support improves.

WDYT?

issue.title: Lack of versioning on the dependencies causes trouble
issue.body: **Describe the bug** Lack of versioning on the dependencies: * makes downloads idempotent (2 downloads might not yield the same result) * makes imposible to run `npm audits` * doesn't let GitHub's dependabot automatically create a PR to update a version whenever a vulnerability is found This is a request to revert #1278 and reset specific versions in package.json and add a package-lock.json. I know that it adds a bit of a maintenance. But dependabot will take care of the crucial stuff, it's not so hard to every now and then do a general update of dependencies (in my own OSS packages I do so before cutting new releases) and it will provide great benefits. I'm happy to set all the latests versions and create the package-lock.json, and create a PR if it would be welcomed. **To Reproduce** Steps to reproduce the behavior on a MacBook with Node 18.0.0: 1. npm install 2. npm test **Expected behavior** The tests run successfully. Which only happens after manually reinstalling the latest Karma version. **Screenshots** When running `TEST_BROWSER_NAME=ChromeHeadless npm test` I get: When running `npm test` and opening the browser I get the same: **Client (please complete the following information):** - OS: MacOS - Browser: All browsers - Browser version: [e.g. 22] **Server (please complete the following information):** - noVNC version: latests - VNC server: not relevant - WebSocket proxy: not relevant

comment.body:
> That is still a bit different than the use case for the package lock. The lock is extremely specific and is for 100% reproducible deployments. We¹ don't do deployments. We do development of a component.

I would't say that it's for reproducible deployment.
It's for deterministic installs.
And that is important for your 2 user groups: end users of noVNC (i.e. people that use solutions based on noVNC) and developer of noVNC (people, like me, that contribute to the project and most likely building solutions for users using noVNC).

Your end users do deployments of (solutions that include) noVNC and they want to know what they are deploying.
They want to generate a BOM of their solution and check if there are known vulnerabilities.
E.g., A couple of years ago I used noVNC on a project while I was working in a highly regulated industry.
We build a no-VNC solution to manage testing environments. This solution included noVNC and it was mandatory to control the versions of all library and validate them (we couldn't even pull directly from npm). So, I ended up forking the project and having to spend the double effort to offer deterministic dependencies to the end user since the project itself doesn't.

I understand that Cendio as a company, sells its own noVNC-based solution to it's customers and that's your priority. That's totally fair and I totally support this. I'm sure that when you package your solution to deliver it, you know exactly which versions of dependencies are going in and do your security checks.
However, noVNC is an open-source projects, so you should keep in mind the end users that are not direct Cendio customers. I think that it's a responsible thing to make it as safe as posible for other consumers of noVNC as well as for the Cendio client.

Your developers, like me, download the repo and work on it locally.
Without having the concrete dependencies, thinks like what happen to me might happen.
E.g., Karma release version 7 which is incompatible with 6. All the sudden, I run an install and things don't work.
Until someone creates a PR fixing the config, the solution won't work unless you manually change the version back to 6.


> What we want here is a Karma which is new enough to support what we need. Which admittedly isn't '*'. But it also isn't '6.4.1'. It's rather '>= 5', or whatever version it is, that we are currently implicitly assuming. I have no objections to adding something like that. It would be similar to how we try to keep track of which browser versions we require.

If you see my example just above. I don't think that it's exactly like that.
You don't need an exact version. But you don't always need the latest.
Let me give you another example.
Karma 6.4.1 is found to have a severe vulnerability. You could simply set 6.4.0 and make sure that your users are safe (or dependabot might do it for you). However, if you simply use `latest`, this won't be the case.

> This is a problem caused by the lock file, so not a missing benefit. If we don't block updates, then we won't block security fixes.

Not really.
You might have a vulnerability present in all packages newer than 6.4.1 where the latest is 6.4.5.
While the team solves the issue, you might be able to simply use 6.4.0. However, if you simply get latests and the dependency team doesn't fix the issue for a while. You are stuck with the vulnerability.

Also, if I run `npm install` and get a specific version. Even if in the future I run it again, npm detects that there ir already a valid package in `node_modules` and doesn't update.

> It seems you can use tags, so I think what we want is

npm tags are tricky.
If a library with a latests 7.5.1 releases a vulnerability fix for it as 7.5.2 and then back-port the fix for version 6.8.2 so users of v6 can still get the fix in, the latest tag will point to 6.8.2 unless the maintainer manually changes it.
This is something that I have seen in a few cases.


Sorry for the very long response.
I just wanted to make it very clear that this is not about me having to manually update some dependencies.
It's about compliance and about making things easier for developers and end users that rely on noVNC.

>  Because I cannot reproduce it here

That's exactly the problem 😅
npm installs are not deterministic without a `package-lock.json`.
The install that I get, is not the same that I get and it's not the same that some other contributor or user might get.

Since npm 7 they went further and they are not only deterministic on the versions being installed but also on the directory structure (see [blog post](https://blog.npmjs.org/post/621733939456933888/npm-v7-series-why-keep-package-lockjson.html)).


> how it is related to the problem you are seeing.
What exactly is triggering those problems?

When I do a clean `npm install`, Karma resolves to an old version.
This is probably due to some internal dependency requiring that all version and noVNC requiring any (`*`) version.
So I get an old Karma version that doesn't work.

The solution is to run `npm install karma` after `npm install` which installs the latest version of Karma and solves the issue.


> And how would a package lock help?

A package lock will make installs deterministic and will indicate exactly which dependencies have been proven to work.
Everyone will get the exact same dependency tree and folder directory and there will never be an "it works in my machine" type of issue. Regardess of how uncommon this type of issue might be.

As additional benefits:

Having strict dependencies would allow contributors to run `npm audit` and identify vulnerabilities in the library and would allow that github dependabot automatically create PRs when vulnerabilities are found. Dependabot runs automatically in all GitHub public repos. See an [example](https://github.com/juanjoDiaz/serverless-plugin-warmup/pull/238) in one of my projects.

Having a package lock also would allow us to use `https://docs.npmjs.com/cli/v8/commands/npm-ci` which guarantees 100% that you get what the lock file says whereas npm install simple installs whatever is missing in the `node_modules` folder.

issue.title: Add automatic coverage results and badge using coveralls, codecov or similar
issue.body:
To continue with #13.

At the moment, the coverage badge is manually created and clicking it goes nowhere.
Instead we should send our coverage results to a service like coverall, codecov, etc. so the badge is automatically generated and when clicking you go to that platform to see a complete report.
You can look at the coverage badge on https://github.com/juanjoDiaz/serverless-plugin-warmup if you don't know what I mean.

I tried setting up coveralls since it's what I use in all my OSS projects but I found that phpunit doesn't support the LCOV reporting format. Based on https://github.com/sebastianbergmann/php-code-coverage/pull/869 and https://github.com/sebastianbergmann/php-code-coverage/issues/735 the project seems quite dead and support won't come any time soon. So we need to either find a way to convert php unit results to lcov or look at alternatives.

comment.body:
Codecov seems to support cobertura which is also supported by phpunit.

There might be newer and better solutions. This are just the ones that I know of 🙂

I know that it adds a bit of a maintenance. issue.title: Add automatic clipboard support
issue.body:
This PR adds support for automatic copy-pasting.
So when you are focused on the canvas and paste text it's pasted in the server and when you copy something in the server it's automatically copied to your local keyboard.

I've seen #1301 and #1174. But this takes a very different approach since it adds support for copy-pasting to noVNC's core. And I think that it's quite cleaner.

I've tested it in Safari, Firefox, and Chrome.
Unfortunately, the Clipboard API is only supported by Chrome and the `paste` event is broken (see https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=634426).
So it just does nothing in Safari and Firefox, while in Chrome the copying of data works but not the pasting.

So, for now, this is not super useful but it should become better as browser support improves.

WDYT?

comment.body:
Indeed. Re-installing Karma manually re-installed the latest version and fixed the issue.
I'll open a separate issue about that.

issue.title: Client attribute mapper

labels.name: kind/feature
labels.description: Categorizes a PR related to a new feature

issue.body:
### Description

User attributes are a first class citizen.
They have their own tab on the user view of the admin portal and they have a mapper so they can be included in tokens.

Clients attributes are second class citizens.
They do NOT have their own tab and must be managed through the Admin API, and they can't be mapped to be included in tokens.

I propose to bring parity to these two.
It doesn't seem like this is a new idea. Someone already asked for this a few years ago: https://lists.jboss.org/pipermail/keycloak-user/2016-March/005447.html

### Discussion

_No response_

### Motivation

I own a public API and use Keycloack to provide authentication and authorization.
I register all consumers of my API as client with only service account enabled so they can get tokens and call my API.
I'm adding some metadata to each client to be included in the token so my API has more information.

Standard use case, just as you would do for a user, but a client.

### Details

_No response_

issue.title: Add support for organizations
issue.body:
As an organization manager, I would like to be able to control who can access my packages so I can give access to new employees and also remove leavers.

At the moment this has to be done package by package, which can get burdensome if your number of packages grows.

Ideally, there should be something like "organizations" where organizations admins can manage users belonging to the org. Similar to what GitHub, NPM, etc.. offer.

This would also be a great way to control vendor namespace ownership. The current approach of "if you are in a single repo, you have access to the whole namespace" is a bit flaky. What if you have an external contributing to a single package?

Something like SSO would be just awesome, but I consider that more of a paid enterprise feature.

issue.title: Path of .middleware folder when searching for modules is broken with default folderName in Serverless 3.0
issue.body:
The path of the .middleware folder using the default configuration is broken in serverless 3.0 + serverless-middleware 3.0.

```
Framework Core: 3.22.0 (local) 3.21.0 (global)
Plugin: 6.2.2
SDK: 4.3.2
```

Error: ``` Error: Cannot find module '/project-name/.build/.middleware/service-name-functionName'```

Serverless for some reason is assuming that the ```/.middleware/``` directory is located inside of ```/.build/.middleware/``` and that is not the default location of the folder.

The ```pathToRoot``` variable resolves to just ```..``` without a preceding slash, (```../```) and I thought that was the problem although manually altering the following did not fix it.  Although, it does print out the preceding slash in the logs and doesn't seem to hurt anything.  Not sure if *not* adding a preceding slash was intentional or not.

```const pathToRoot = path.relative(pathFolder, this.serviceDir);``` - original
```const pathToRoot = path.relative(pathFolder, this.serviceDir) + '/';``` - modified

If I find a fix, I'm happy to commit it but since you likely can pinpoint it faster, I'm posting this for visibility into the issue as well as for archival purposes.

comment.body:
Hi @bcrigler ,

Thanks for the deep research on the issue:

Can you create a repo so I can reproduce the issue? Then it will be a lot easier for me to fix it.

The **Transpilation Issue** is by design. This plugin glue together all the middlewares into a single handler in whatever your original language was. Then it's up to you to use a separate plugin to do the transpilation.

So, the problem I think is the order in which you are using the plugin.
Both the typescrypt and the middleware plugins mingle with paths and handlers, typescript creates `.build` and middleware creates `.middleware`, and that's probably causing the error.
Changing the order so the middleware plugin runs before the typescript plugin probably fixes the issue.

```yaml
plugins:
  - serverless-middleware
  - serverless-plugin-typescript
  - serverless-plugin-common-excludes
  - serverless-plugin-include-dependencies
  - serverless-offline
```

If it doesn't work, can you provide a sample project so I can reproduce the issue and work on it?

pull_request.title: feat: optionally set warmer roleName if using default role
pull_request.body:
Optionally set a roleName for the warmers.

## **Use Case:** 
Sometimes the default generated Role name exceeds the IAM max name length of 64 characters.

This causes deployments to fail for some users if they do not disable the warmers for deployments. 

### **Example:**
```
Error:
CREATE_FAILED: WarmUpPluginDefaultRole (AWS::IAM::Role)
1 validation error detected: Value 'apple-map-api-sandbox-ap-south-1-stack-sandbox-ap-south-1-default-role' at 'roleName' failed to satisfy constraint: Member must have length less than or equal to 64 (Service: AmazonIdentityManagement; Status Code: 400; Error Code: ValidationError; Request ID: 60b62c0f-18d8-4b63-80fe-672b1b5d8add; Proxy: null)
```
## **Cause:**
https://github.com/juanjoDiaz/serverless-plugin-warmup/blob/847b45cc675e8f12ea439b68283417feab562ef9/src/warmer.js#L25-L40


## **Fix:** 

Optionally provide warmer RoleName field for two main reasons:
1. Allow users to follow a specific naming structure across their accounts
2. Provide a workaround for the max character limit for IAM Role names. 


-----

`Please let me know if I have missed anything... Thanks!`

pull_request.title: feat: optionally set warmer roleName if using default role
pull_request.body:
Optionally set a roleName for the warmers.

## **Use Case:** 
Sometimes the default generated Role name exceeds the IAM max name length of 64 characters.

This causes deployments to fail for some users if they do not disable the warmers for deployments. 

### **Example:**
```
Error:
CREATE_FAILED: WarmUpPluginDefaultRole (AWS::IAM::Role)
1 validation error detected: Value 'apple-map-api-sandbox-ap-south-1-stack-sandbox-ap-south-1-default-role' at 'roleName' failed to satisfy constraint: Member must have length less than or equal to 64 (Service: AmazonIdentityManagement; Status Code: 400; Error Code: ValidationError; Request ID: 60b62c0f-18d8-4b63-80fe-672b1b5d8add; Proxy: null)
```
## **Cause:**
https://github.com/juanjoDiaz/serverless-plugin-warmup/blob/847b45cc675e8f12ea439b68283417feab562ef9/src/warmer.js#L25-L40


## **Fix:** 

Optionally provide warmer RoleName field for two main reasons:
1. Allow users to follow a specific naming structure across their accounts
2. Provide a workaround for the max character limit for IAM Role names. 


-----

`Please let me know if I have missed anything... Thanks!`

issue.title: Cannot find module 'handler'
issue.body:
Hello, I'm submitting the issue cause this error is throwing me in my serverless project after upgrading the `serverless-plugin-warmup` from version `4.9.0` to `8.0.0`.

```
ERROR	Uncaught Exception 	
{
    "errorType": "Runtime.ImportModuleError",
    "errorMessage": "Error: Cannot find module 'handler'\nRequire stack:\n- /var/runtime/index.mjs",
    "stack": [
        "Runtime.ImportModuleError: Error: Cannot find module 'handler'",
        "Require stack:",
        "- /var/runtime/index.mjs",
        "    at _loadUserApp (file:///var/runtime/index.mjs:951:17)",
        "    at async Object.UserFunction.js.module.exports.load (file:///var/runtime/index.mjs:976:21)",
        "    at async start (file:///var/runtime/index.mjs:1137:23)",
        "    at async file:///var/runtime/index.mjs:1143:1"
    ]
}
```
I know that `serverless-plugin-warmup` is working because it created the Warm Up Lambda with its configuration. But after that, all lambda functions can't be found, even if the lambda doesn't have the warm-up event, it can't be found.

Versions:
```
NodeJs: 16.x
Serverless: ~3.19.0
Serverless Plugin Warmup: ^8.0.0
Serverless Webpack:  5.9.1
Serverless Offline: 9.1.0
```
The functions configuration declared in the `serverless.yml` hasn´t been modified because previously the `serverless-plugin-warmup` every function was working and also, using `serverless-offline`, the project is working fine.

---
The `warmup` configuration in `serverless.yml`
```
warmup:
    default:
      cleanFolder: false
      name: custom-Name-Lambda
      events:
        - schedule: 'rate(5 minutes)'
      package:
        individually: false
      prewarm: true
      concurrency: 10 # Warm up 10 concurrent instances
```

issue.title: Packaging should not include service level patterns
issue.body:
We have the following config which adds all python code also into the `warmUpPluginOfficeHoursWarmer.zip`. I tried various variations to exclude the files and the only thing that worked is setting `package.individually` to `true` or moving the package block into the function. Moving the package block into the function does not apply the patterns though and we will end up with a large zip file.

Imo `package.patterns` should not be joined to package the warmer function.

```yaml
functions:
  app:
    handler: wsgi_handler.handler
    timeout: 30
    layers:
      - Ref: PythonRequirementsLambdaLayer
    warmup:
      officeHoursWarmer:
        enabled: prod

package:
  individually: false
  patterns:
    - "!**"
    - "serverless_sdk*/**"
    - "app/**"
    - "module1/**"
    - "module2/**"
    - "module3/**"
    - "*.py"
```

What worked:
```yaml
functions:
  app:
    handler: wsgi_handler.handler
    timeout: 30
    layers:
      - Ref: PythonRequirementsLambdaLayer
    package:
      patterns:
        - "!**"
        - "serverless_sdk*/**"
        - "app/**"
        - "module1/**"
        - "module2/**"
        - "module3/**"
        - "*.py"
    warmup:
      officeHoursWarmer:
        enabled: prod

package:
  individually: true
```

comment.body:
Hi @estahn ,

Cascading the package settings (i.e. joining the patterns set at package level  to the ones set at the function) is the behaviour of the Serverless framework.

You can also exclude the packages from the warmer config:

```yaml
package:
  individually: false
  patterns:
    - "!**"
    - "serverless_sdk*/**"
    - "app/**"
    - "module1/**"
    - "module2/**"
    - "module3/**"
    - "*.py"

custom:
  warmup:
    default:
      enabled: true
      package:
        patterns:
          - "!serverless_sdk*/**"
          - "!app/**"
          - "!module1/**"
          - "!module2/**"
          - "!module3/**"
          - "!*.py"

functions:
  app:
    handler: wsgi_handler.handler
    timeout: 30
    layers:
      - Ref: PythonRequirementsLambdaLayer
    warmup:
      officeHoursWarmer:
        enabled: prod
```

issue.body:
My `serverless.yml`:

```yml
...
frameworkVersion: "3"

provider:
  name: aws
  region: eu-west-2
  ecr:
    images:
      predgene_faf_1:
        path: ./
        file: Dockerfile_faf_1
...
functions:
  predictGene_faf_1:
    timeout: ${self:custom.timeout}
    image:
      name: predgene_faf_1
    environment:
      MODEL_PATH: "./model_weights_onnx/faf/17012021-173755-InceptionV3-100e-128bs-0.0001lr.onnx"
      BUCKET: ${self:custom.s3bucket.${sls:stage}.name}
    warmup:
      default:
        enabled:
          - dev
          - prod
...
custom:
  warmup:
    default:
      enabled: true
      events:
        - schedule: cron(0/5 1-23 ? * MON-SUN *)
      concurrency: 5
      verbose: true
      logRetentionInDays: 14
```

My setup:
```json
{
  "dependencies": {
    "serverless": "^3.21.0"
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "serverless-plugin-warmup": "^7.3.0",
    "serverless-prune-plugin": "^2.0.1"
  }
}
```

In my handler:

```python
def handler(event, context, model=None):
    """Handler function for first model of eye2gene"""

    version = "0.3.0"

    if event.get("source") == "serverless-plugin-warmup":
        print("WarmUp - Lambda is warm!")
        return {}
...
```
And then, after a while without checking or using my lambda, I saw this with simple script I use to check:

```
>>> faf 1
        "State": "Inactive",
        "StateReason": "The function is currently idle.",
        "StateReasonCode": "Idle",
````

How can I know that warmup plugin is supposed to be doing its job? Where are the logs referred in `logRetentionInDays`?

comment.body:
That problem happens because you are using Serverless Dashboard and it uses a Serverless internal plugin that messes up things.

Until the issues is fixed on Serverless side, the solution that people uses seems to be the one on https://github.com/juanjoDiaz/serverless-plugin-warmup/issues/293#issuecomment-1173211662

issue.title: Path of .middleware folder when searching for modules is broken with default folderName in Serverless 3.0
issue.body:
The path of the .middleware folder using the default configuration is broken in serverless 3.0 + serverless-middleware 3.0.

```
Framework Core: 3.22.0 (local) 3.21.0 (global)
Plugin: 6.2.2
SDK: 4.3.2
```

Error: ``` Error: Cannot find module '/project-name/.build/.middleware/service-name-functionName'```

Serverless for some reason is assuming that the ```/.middleware/``` directory is located inside of ```/.build/.middleware/``` and that is not the default location of the folder.

The ```pathToRoot``` variable resolves to just ```..``` without a preceding slash, (```../```) and I thought that was the problem although manually altering the following did not fix it.  Although, it does print out the preceding slash in the logs and doesn't seem to hurt anything.  Not sure if *not* adding a preceding slash was intentional or not.

```const pathToRoot = path.relative(pathFolder, this.serviceDir);``` - original
```const pathToRoot = path.relative(pathFolder, this.serviceDir) + '/';``` - modified

If I find a fix, I'm happy to commit it but since you likely can pinpoint it faster, I'm posting this for visibility into the issue as well as for archival purposes.

issue.body:

```

Error: ``` Error: Cannot find module '/project-name/.build/.middleware/service-name-functionName'```

Serverless for some reason is assuming that the ```/.middleware/``` directory is located inside of ```/.build/.middleware/``` and that is not the default location of the folder.

The ```pathToRoot``` variable resolves to just ```..``` without a preceding slash, (```../```) and I thought that was the problem although manually altering the following did not fix it.  Although, it does print out the preceding slash in the logs and doesn't seem to hurt anything.  Not sure if *not* adding a preceding slash was intentional or not.

```const pathToRoot = path.relative(pathFolder, this.serviceDir);``` - original
```const pathToRoot = path.relative(pathFolder, this.serviceDir) + '/';``` - modified

If I find a fix, I'm happy to commit it but since you likely can pinpoint it faster, I'm posting this for visibility into the issue as well as for archival purposes.

issue.title: Lack of versioning on the dependencies causes trouble
issue.body: **Describe the bug** Lack of versioning on the dependencies: * makes downloads idempotent (2 downloads might not yield the same result) * makes imposible to run `npm audits` * doesn't let GitHub's dependabot automatically create a PR to update a version whenever a vulnerability is found This is a request to revert #1278 and reset specific versions in package.json and add a package-lock.json. I know that it adds a bit of a maintenance. But dependabot will take care of the crucial stuff, it's not so hard to every now and then do a general update of dependencies (in my own OSS packages I do so before cutting new releases) and it will provide great benefits. I'm happy to set all the latests versions and create the package-lock.json, and create a PR if it would be welcomed. **To Reproduce** Steps to reproduce the behavior on a MacBook with Node 18.0.0: 1. npm install 2. npm test **Expected behavior** The tests run successfully. Which only happens after manually reinstalling the latest Karma version. **Screenshots** When running `TEST_BROWSER_NAME=ChromeHeadless npm test` I get: When running `npm test` and opening the browser I get the same: **Client (please complete the following information):** - OS: MacOS - Browser: All browsers - Browser version: [e.g. 22] **Server (please complete the following information):** - noVNC version: latests - VNC server: not relevant - WebSocket proxy: not relevant

comment.body:
Hi guys,

I really don't think that keeping dependencies up-to-date is such a big effort.
It's a matter of having a recurring task to run
```sh
// See outdated dependencies
npm outdated
// Automatically update all minor/patch version
npm update
// Fix vulnerabilities updating minor/patch versions
npm audit fix
```

It could be put in a scheduled action or even I or some other contributor could put something in my calendar and do a PR once a month or so.

From my point of view, one of the main advantages of open-sourcing a project is that you get a bunch of eyes on the code and you benefit from the crowd to identify vulnerabilities, bugs, etc.
Leaving this to individual developers removes that benefit and forces each and every developer to play around with dependencies to get things to work (if something like my karma issue happens) and to lock dependencies and do a full round of testing to ensure that everything works and there are no vulnerabilities.

That said, I've tried to explain why I think that this is a good idea and an improvement to the project.
But at the end of the day, you guys are the owners.
So it's up to you...

    warmup:

...

    default:

```

My setup:

{

def handler(event, context, model=None):

issue.title: Lack of versioning on the dependencies causes trouble
issue.body: **Describe the bug** Lack of versioning on the dependencies: * makes downloads idempotent (2 downloads might not yield the same result) * makes imposible to run `npm audits` * doesn't let GitHub's dependabot automatically create a PR to update a version whenever a vulnerability is found This is a request to revert #1278 and reset specific versions in package.json and add a package-lock.json. I know that it adds a bit of a maintenance. But dependabot will take care of the crucial stuff, it's not so hard to every now and then do a general update of dependencies (in my own OSS packages I do so before cutting new releases) and it will provide great benefits. I'm happy to set all the latests versions and create the package-lock.json, and create a PR if it would be welcomed. **To Reproduce** Steps to reproduce the behavior on a MacBook with Node 18.0.0: 1. npm install 2. npm test **Expected behavior** The tests run successfully. Which only happens after manually reinstalling the latest Karma version. **Screenshots** When running `TEST_BROWSER_NAME=ChromeHeadless npm test` I get: When running `npm test` and opening the browser I get the same: **Client (please complete the following information):** - OS: MacOS - Browser: All browsers - Browser version: [e.g. 22] **Server (please complete the following information):** - noVNC version: latests - VNC server: not relevant - WebSocket proxy: not relevant

comment.body:
> That is still a bit different than the use case for the package lock. The lock is extremely specific and is for 100% reproducible deployments. We¹ don't do deployments. We do development of a component.

I would't say that it's for reproducible deployment.
It's for deterministic installs.
And that is important for your 2 user groups: end users of noVNC (i.e. people that use solutions based on noVNC) and developer of noVNC (people, like me, that contribute to the project and most likely building solutions for users using noVNC).

Your end users do deployments of (solutions that include) noVNC and they want to know what they are deploying.
They want to generate a BOM of their solution and check if there are known vulnerabilities.
E.g., A couple of years ago I used noVNC on a project while I was working in a highly regulated industry.
We build a no-VNC solution to manage testing environments. This solution included noVNC and it was mandatory to control the versions of all library and validate them (we couldn't even pull directly from npm). So, I ended up forking the project and having to spend the double effort to offer deterministic dependencies to the end user since the project itself doesn't.

I understand that Cendio as a company, sells its own noVNC-based solution to it's customers and that's your priority. That's totally fair and I totally support this. I'm sure that when you package your solution to deliver it, you know exactly which versions of dependencies are going in and do your security checks.
However, noVNC is an open-source projects, so you should keep in mind the end users that are not direct Cendio customers. I think that it's a responsible thing to make it as safe as posible for other consumers of noVNC as well as for the Cendio client.

Your developers, like me, download the repo and work on it locally.
Without having the concrete dependencies, thinks like what happen to me might happen.
E.g., Karma release version 7 which is incompatible with 6. All the sudden, I run an install and things don't work.
Until someone creates a PR fixing the config, the solution won't work unless you manually change the version back to 6.


> What we want here is a Karma which is new enough to support what we need. Which admittedly isn't '*'. But it also isn't '6.4.1'. It's rather '>= 5', or whatever version it is, that we are currently implicitly assuming. I have no objections to adding something like that. It would be similar to how we try to keep track of which browser versions we require.

If you see my example just above. I don't think that it's exactly like that.
You don't need an exact version. But you don't always need the latest.
Let me give you another example.
Karma 6.4.1 is found to have a severe vulnerability. You could simply set 6.4.0 and make sure that your users are safe (or dependabot might do it for you). However, if you simply use `latest`, this won't be the case.

> This is a problem caused by the lock file, so not a missing benefit. If we don't block updates, then we won't block security fixes.

Not really.
You might have a vulnerability present in all packages newer than 6.4.1 where the latest is 6.4.5.
While the team solves the issue, you might be able to simply use 6.4.0. However, if you simply get latests and the dependency team doesn't fix the issue for a while. You are stuck with the vulnerability.

Also, if I run `npm install` and get a specific version. Even if in the future I run it again, npm detects that there ir already a valid package in `node_modules` and doesn't update.

> It seems you can use tags, so I think what we want is

npm tags are tricky.
If a library with a latests 7.5.1 releases a vulnerability fix for it as 7.5.2 and then back-port the fix for version 6.8.2 so users of v6 can still get the fix in, the latest tag will point to 6.8.2 unless the maintainer manually changes it.
This is something that I have seen in a few cases.


Sorry for the very long response.
I just wanted to make it very clear that this is not about me having to manually update some dependencies.
It's about compliance and about making things easier for developers and end users that rely on noVNC.

issue.title: Lack of versioning on the dependencies causes trouble
issue.body: **Describe the bug** Lack of versioning on the dependencies: * makes downloads idempotent (2 downloads might not yield the same result) * makes imposible to run `npm audits` * doesn't let GitHub's dependabot automatically create a PR to update a version whenever a vulnerability is found This is a request to revert #1278 and reset specific versions in package.json and add a package-lock.json. I know that it adds a bit of a maintenance. But dependabot will take care of the crucial stuff, it's not so hard to every now and then do a general update of dependencies (in my own OSS packages I do so before cutting new releases) and it will provide great benefits. I'm happy to set all the latests versions and create the package-lock.json, and create a PR if it would be welcomed. **To Reproduce** Steps to reproduce the behavior on a MacBook with Node 18.0.0: 1. npm install 2. npm test **Expected behavior** The tests run successfully. Which only happens after manually reinstalling the latest Karma version. **Screenshots** When running `TEST_BROWSER_NAME=ChromeHeadless npm test` I get: When running `npm test` and opening the browser I get the same: **Client (please complete the following information):** - OS: MacOS - Browser: All browsers - Browser version: [e.g. 22] **Server (please complete the following information):** - noVNC version: latests - VNC server: not relevant - WebSocket proxy: not relevant

comment.body:
Hi Pierre,

>  Because I cannot reproduce it here

That's exactly the problem 😅
npm installs are not deterministic without a `package-lock.json`.
The install that I get, is not the same that I get and it's not the same that some other contributor or user might get.

Since npm 7 they went further and they are not only deterministic on the versions being installed but also on the directory structure (see [blog post](https://blog.npmjs.org/post/621733939456933888/npm-v7-series-why-keep-package-lockjson.html)).


> how it is related to the problem you are seeing.
What exactly is triggering those problems?

When I do a clean `npm install`, Karma resolves to an old version.
This is probably due to some internal dependency requiring that all version and noVNC requiring any (`*`) version.
So I get an old Karma version that doesn't work.

The solution is to run `npm install karma` after `npm install` which installs the latest version of Karma and solves the issue.


> And how would a package lock help?

A package lock will make installs deterministic and will indicate exactly which dependencies have been proven to work.
Everyone will get the exact same dependency tree and folder directory and there will never be an "it works in my machine" type of issue. Regardess of how uncommon this type of issue might be.

As additional benefits:

Having strict dependencies would allow contributors to run `npm audit` and identify vulnerabilities in the library and would allow that github dependabot automatically create PRs when vulnerabilities are found. Dependabot runs automatically in all GitHub public repos. See an [example](https://github.com/juanjoDiaz/serverless-plugin-warmup/pull/238) in one of my projects.

Having a package lock also would allow us to use `https://docs.npmjs.com/cli/v8/commands/npm-ci` which guarantees 100% that you get what the lock file says whereas npm install simple installs whatever is missing in the `node_modules` folder.

issue.title: Add automatic coverage results and badge using coveralls, codecov or similar
issue.body:
To continue with #13.

At the moment, the coverage badge is manually created and clicking it goes nowhere.
Instead we should send our coverage results to a service like coverall, codecov, etc. so the badge is automatically generated and when clicking you go to that platform to see a complete report.
You can look at the coverage badge on https://github.com/juanjoDiaz/serverless-plugin-warmup if you don't know what I mean.

I tried setting up coveralls since it's what I use in all my OSS projects but I found that phpunit doesn't support the LCOV reporting format. Based on https://github.com/sebastianbergmann/php-code-coverage/pull/869 and https://github.com/sebastianbergmann/php-code-coverage/issues/735 the project seems quite dead and support won't come any time soon. So we need to either find a way to convert php unit results to lcov or look at alternatives.

comment.body:
Codecov seems to support cobertura which is also supported by phpunit.

There might be newer and better solutions. This are just the ones that I know of 🙂

issue.title: Client attribute mapper

labels.name: kind/feature
labels.description: Categorizes a PR related to a new feature

issue.body:
### Description

User attributes are a first class citizen.
They have their own tab on the user view of the admin portal and they have a mapper so they can be included in tokens.

Clients attributes are second class citizens.
They do NOT have their own tab and must be managed through the Admin API, and they can't be mapped to be included in tokens.

I propose to bring parity to these two.
It doesn't seem like this is a new idea. Someone already asked for this a few years ago: https://lists.jboss.org/pipermail/keycloak-user/2016-March/005447.html

### Discussion

_No response_

### Motivation

I own a public API and use Keycloack to provide authentication and authorization.
I register all consumers of my API as client with only service account enabled so they can get tokens and call my API.
I'm adding some metadata to each client to be included in the token so my API has more information.

Standard use case, just as you would do for a user, but a client.

### Details

_No response_

issue.title: Add support for organizations
issue.body:
As an organization manager, I would like to be able to control who can access my packages so I can give access to new employees and also remove leavers.

At the moment this has to be done package by package, which can get burdensome if your number of packages grows.

Ideally, there should be something like "organizations" where organizations admins can manage users belonging to the org. Similar to what GitHub, NPM, etc.. offer.

This would also be a great way to control vendor namespace ownership. The current approach of "if you are in a single repo, you have access to the whole namespace" is a bit flaky. What if you have an external contributing to a single package?

Something like SSO would be just awesome, but I consider that more of a paid enterprise feature.

issue.title: Add automatic clipboard support
issue.body:
This PR adds support for automatic copy-pasting.
So when you are focused on the canvas and paste text it's pasted in the server and when you copy something in the server it's automatically copied to your local keyboard.

I've seen #1301 and #1174. But this takes a very different approach since it adds support for copy-pasting to noVNC's core. And I think that it's quite cleaner.

I've tested it in Safari, Firefox, and Chrome.
Unfortunately, the Clipboard API is only supported by Chrome and the `paste` event is broken (see https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=634426).
So it just does nothing in Safari and Firefox, while in Chrome the copying of data works but not the pasting.

So, for now, this is not super useful but it should become better as browser support improves.

WDYT?

comment.body:
Happy to see that this is relevant almost 3 years later 😅

According to [MDN](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Clipboard_API),  support should be now there for most mayor browsers.

And, as I said back then, adding functionality to copy-paste that works in most browsers, and doesn't break anything in browsers without support should be a positive addition. Plus, having a clipboard module is a good foundation for future improvements and to add possible workarounds and support for other browsers.

I'd be happy to rebase this change and take a look at anything else needed if there is an intention to get this in 😊

issue.title: Path of .middleware folder when searching for modules is broken with default folderName in Serverless 3.0
issue.body:
The path of the .middleware folder using the default configuration is broken in serverless 3.0 + serverless-middleware 3.0.

```
Framework Core: 3.22.0 (local) 3.21.0 (global)
Plugin: 6.2.2
SDK: 4.3.2
```

Error: ``` Error: Cannot find module '/project-name/.build/.middleware/service-name-functionName'```

Serverless for some reason is assuming that the ```/.middleware/``` directory is located inside of ```/.build/.middleware/``` and that is not the default location of the folder.

The ```pathToRoot``` variable resolves to just ```..``` without a preceding slash, (```../```) and I thought that was the problem although manually altering the following did not fix it.  Although, it does print out the preceding slash in the logs and doesn't seem to hurt anything.  Not sure if *not* adding a preceding slash was intentional or not.

```const pathToRoot = path.relative(pathFolder, this.serviceDir);``` - original
```const pathToRoot = path.relative(pathFolder, this.serviceDir) + '/';``` - modified

If I find a fix, I'm happy to commit it but since you likely can pinpoint it faster, I'm posting this for visibility into the issue as well as for archival purposes.

comment.body:
Hi @bcrigler ,

Thanks for the deep research on the issue:

Can you create a repo so I can reproduce the issue? Then it will be a lot easier for me to fix it.

The **Transpilation Issue** is by design. This plugin glue together all the middlewares into a single handler in whatever your original language was. Then it's up to you to use a separate plugin to do the transpilation.

So, the problem I think is the order in which you are using the plugin.
Both the typescrypt and the middleware plugins mingle with paths and handlers, typescript creates `.build` and middleware creates `.middleware`, and that's probably causing the error.
Changing the order so the middleware plugin runs before the typescript plugin probably fixes the issue.

```yaml
plugins:
  - serverless-middleware
  - serverless-plugin-typescript
  - serverless-plugin-common-excludes
  - serverless-plugin-include-dependencies
  - serverless-offline
```

If it doesn't work, can you provide a sample project so I can reproduce the issue and work on it?

pull_request.title: feat: optionally set warmer roleName if using default role
pull_request.body:
Optionally set a roleName for the warmers.

## **Use Case:** 
Sometimes the default generated Role name exceeds the IAM max name length of 64 characters.

This causes deployments to fail for some users if they do not disable the warmers for deployments. 

### **Example:**
```
Error:
CREATE_FAILED: WarmUpPluginDefaultRole (AWS::IAM::Role)
1 validation error detected: Value 'apple-map-api-sandbox-ap-south-1-stack-sandbox-ap-south-1-default-role' at 'roleName' failed to satisfy constraint: Member must have length less than or equal to 64 (Service: AmazonIdentityManagement; Status Code: 400; Error Code: ValidationError; Request ID: 60b62c0f-18d8-4b63-80fe-672b1b5d8add; Proxy: null)
```
## **Cause:**
https://github.com/juanjoDiaz/serverless-plugin-warmup/blob/847b45cc675e8f12ea439b68283417feab562ef9/src/warmer.js#L25-L40


## **Fix:** 

Optionally provide warmer RoleName field for two main reasons:
1. Allow users to follow a specific naming structure across their accounts
2. Provide a workaround for the max character limit for IAM Role names. 


-----

`Please let me know if I have missed anything... Thanks!`

issue.title: Cannot find module 'handler'
issue.body:
Hello, I'm submitting the issue cause this error is throwing me in my serverless project after upgrading the `serverless-plugin-warmup` from version `4.9.0` to `8.0.0`.

```
ERROR	Uncaught Exception 	
{
    "errorType": "Runtime.ImportModuleError",
    "errorMessage": "Error: Cannot find module 'handler'\nRequire stack:\n- /var/runtime/index.mjs",
    "stack": [
        "Runtime.ImportModuleError: Error: Cannot find module 'handler'",
        "Require stack:",
        "- /var/runtime/index.mjs",
        "    at _loadUserApp (file:///var/runtime/index.mjs:951:17)",
        "    at async Object.UserFunction.js.module.exports.load (file:///var/runtime/index.mjs:976:21)",
        "    at async start (file:///var/runtime/index.mjs:1137:23)",
        "    at async file:///var/runtime/index.mjs:1143:1"
    ]
}
```
I know that `serverless-plugin-warmup` is working because it created the Warm Up Lambda with its configuration. But after that, all lambda functions can't be found, even if the lambda doesn't have the warm-up event, it can't be found.

Versions:
```
NodeJs: 16.x
Serverless: ~3.19.0
Serverless Plugin Warmup: ^8.0.0
Serverless Webpack:  5.9.1
Serverless Offline: 9.1.0
```
The functions configuration declared in the `serverless.yml` hasn´t been modified because previously the `serverless-plugin-warmup` every function was working and also, using `serverless-offline`, the project is working fine.

---
The `warmup` configuration in `serverless.yml`
```
warmup:
    default:
      cleanFolder: false
      name: custom-Name-Lambda
      events:
        - schedule: 'rate(5 minutes)'
      package:
        individually: false
      prewarm: true
      concurrency: 10 # Warm up 10 concurrent instances
```

issue.title: Packaging should not include service level patterns
issue.body:
We have the following config which adds all python code also into the `warmUpPluginOfficeHoursWarmer.zip`. I tried various variations to exclude the files and the only thing that worked is setting `package.individually` to `true` or moving the package block into the function. Moving the package block into the function does not apply the patterns though and we will end up with a large zip file.

Imo `package.patterns` should not be joined to package the warmer function.

```yaml
functions:
  app:
    handler: wsgi_handler.handler
    timeout: 30
    layers:
      - Ref: PythonRequirementsLambdaLayer
    warmup:
      officeHoursWarmer:
        enabled: prod

package:
  individually: false
  patterns:
    - "!**"
    - "serverless_sdk*/**"
    - "app/**"
    - "module1/**"
    - "module2/**"
    - "module3/**"
    - "*.py"
```

What worked:
```yaml
functions:
  app:
    handler: wsgi_handler.handler
    timeout: 30
    layers:
      - Ref: PythonRequirementsLambdaLayer
    package:
      patterns:
        - "!**"
        - "serverless_sdk*/**"
        - "app/**"
        - "module1/**"
        - "module2/**"
        - "module3/**"
        - "*.py"
    warmup:
      officeHoursWarmer:
        enabled: prod

package:
  individually: true
```

comment.body:
Hi @estahn ,

Cascading the package settings (i.e. joining the patterns set at package level  to the ones set at the function) is the behaviour of the Serverless framework.

You can also exclude the packages from the warmer config:

```yaml
package:
  individually: false
  patterns:
    - "!**"
    - "serverless_sdk*/**"
    - "app/**"
    - "module1/**"
    - "module2/**"
    - "module3/**"
    - "*.py"

custom:
  warmup:
    default:
      enabled: true
      package:
        patterns:
          - "!serverless_sdk*/**"
          - "!app/**"
          - "!module1/**"
          - "!module2/**"
          - "!module3/**"
          - "!*.py"

functions:
  app:
    handler: wsgi_handler.handler
    timeout: 30
    layers:
      - Ref: PythonRequirementsLambdaLayer
    warmup:
      officeHoursWarmer:
        enabled: prod
```

issue.title: Packaging should not include service level patterns
issue.body:
We have the following config which adds all python code also into the `warmUpPluginOfficeHoursWarmer.zip`. I tried various variations to exclude the files and the only thing that worked is setting `package.individually` to `true` or moving the package block into the function. Moving the package block into the function does not apply the patterns though and we will end up with a large zip file.

Imo `package.patterns` should not be joined to package the warmer function.

```yaml
functions:
  app:
    handler: wsgi_handler.handler
    timeout: 30
    layers:
      - Ref: PythonRequirementsLambdaLayer
    warmup:
      officeHoursWarmer:
        enabled: prod

package:
  individually: false
  patterns:
    - "!**"
    - "serverless_sdk*/**"
    - "app/**"
    - "module1/**"
    - "module2/**"
    - "module3/**"
    - "*.py"
```

What worked:
```yaml
functions:
  app:
    handler: wsgi_handler.handler
    timeout: 30
    layers:
      - Ref: PythonRequirementsLambdaLayer
    package:
      patterns:
        - "!**"
        - "serverless_sdk*/**"
        - "app/**"
        - "module1/**"
        - "module2/**"
        - "module3/**"
        - "*.py"
    warmup:
      officeHoursWarmer:
        enabled: prod

package:
  individually: true
```

issue.title: Path of .middleware folder when searching for modules is broken with default folderName in Serverless 3.0
issue.body:
The path of the .middleware folder using the default configuration is broken in serverless 3.0 + serverless-middleware 3.0.

```
Framework Core: 3.22.0 (local) 3.21.0 (global)
Plugin: 6.2.2
SDK: 4.3.2
```

Error: ``` Error: Cannot find module '/project-name/.build/.middleware/service-name-functionName'```

Serverless for some reason is assuming that the ```/.middleware/``` directory is located inside of ```/.build/.middleware/``` and that is not the default location of the folder.

The ```pathToRoot``` variable resolves to just ```..``` without a preceding slash, (```../```) and I thought that was the problem although manually altering the following did not fix it.  Although, it does print out the preceding slash in the logs and doesn't seem to hurt anything.  Not sure if *not* adding a preceding slash was intentional or not.

```const pathToRoot = path.relative(pathFolder, this.serviceDir);``` - original
```const pathToRoot = path.relative(pathFolder, this.serviceDir) + '/';``` - modified

If I find a fix, I'm happy to commit it but since you likely can pinpoint it faster, I'm posting this for visibility into the issue as well as for archival purposes.

issue.title: Lack of versioning on the dependencies causes trouble
issue.body: **Describe the bug** Lack of versioning on the dependencies: * makes downloads idempotent (2 downloads might not yield the same result) * makes imposible to run `npm audits` * doesn't let GitHub's dependabot automatically create a PR to update a version whenever a vulnerability is found This is a request to revert #1278 and reset specific versions in package.json and add a package-lock.json. I know that it adds a bit of a maintenance. But dependabot will take care of the crucial stuff, it's not so hard to every now and then do a general update of dependencies (in my own OSS packages I do so before cutting new releases) and it will provide great benefits. I'm happy to set all the latests versions and create the package-lock.json, and create a PR if it would be welcomed. **To Reproduce** Steps to reproduce the behavior on a MacBook with Node 18.0.0: 1. npm install 2. npm test **Expected behavior** The tests run successfully. Which only happens after manually reinstalling the latest Karma version. **Screenshots** When running `TEST_BROWSER_NAME=ChromeHeadless npm test` I get: When running `npm test` and opening the browser I get the same: **Client (please complete the following information):** - OS: MacOS - Browser: All browsers - Browser version: [e.g. 22] **Server (please complete the following information):** - noVNC version: latests - VNC server: not relevant - WebSocket proxy: not relevant

comment.body:
Hi guys,

I really don't think that keeping dependencies up-to-date is such a big effort.
It's a matter of having a recurring task to run
```sh
// See outdated dependencies
npm outdated
// Automatically update all minor/patch version
npm update
// Fix vulnerabilities updating minor/patch versions
npm audit fix
```

It could be put in a scheduled action or even I or some other contributor could put something in my calendar and do a PR once a month or so.

From my point of view, one of the main advantages of open-sourcing a project is that you get a bunch of eyes on the code and you benefit from the crowd to identify vulnerabilities, bugs, etc.
Leaving this to individual developers removes that benefit and forces each and every developer to play around with dependencies to get things to work (if something like my karma issue happens) and to lock dependencies and do a full round of testing to ensure that everything works and there are no vulnerabilities.

That said, I've tried to explain why I think that this is a good idea and an improvement to the project.
But at the end of the day, you guys are the owners.
So it's up to you...

issue.body:
This PR adds support for automatic copy-pasting.
So when you are focused on the canvas and paste text it's pasted in the server and when you copy something in the server it's automatically copied to your local keyboard.

I've seen #1301 and #1174. But this takes a very different approach since it adds support for copy-pasting to noVNC's core. And I think that it's quite cleaner.

I've tested it in Safari, Firefox, and Chrome.
Unfortunately, the Clipboard API is only supported by Chrome and the `paste` event is broken (see https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=634426).
So it just does nothing in Safari and Firefox, while in Chrome the copying of data works but not the pasting.

So, for now, this is not super useful but it should become better as browser support improves.

WDYT?

issue.title: Lack of versioning on the dependencies causes trouble
issue.body: **Describe the bug** Lack of versioning on the dependencies: * makes downloads idempotent (2 downloads might not yield the same result) * makes imposible to run `npm audits` * doesn't let GitHub's dependabot automatically create a PR to update a version whenever a vulnerability is found This is a request to revert #1278 and reset specific versions in package.json and add a package-lock.json. I know that it adds a bit of a maintenance. But dependabot will take care of the crucial stuff, it's not so hard to every now and then do a general update of dependencies (in my own OSS packages I do so before cutting new releases) and it will provide great benefits. I'm happy to set all the latests versions and create the package-lock.json, and create a PR if it would be welcomed. **To Reproduce** Steps to reproduce the behavior on a MacBook with Node 18.0.0: 1. npm install 2. npm test **Expected behavior** The tests run successfully. Which only happens after manually reinstalling the latest Karma version. **Screenshots** When running `TEST_BROWSER_NAME=ChromeHeadless npm test` I get: When running `npm test` and opening the browser I get the same: **Client (please complete the following information):** - OS: MacOS - Browser: All browsers - Browser version: [e.g. 22] **Server (please complete the following information):** - noVNC version: latests - VNC server: not relevant - WebSocket proxy: not relevant

comment.body:
> That is still a bit different than the use case for the package lock. The lock is extremely specific and is for 100% reproducible deployments. We¹ don't do deployments. We do development of a component.

I would't say that it's for reproducible deployment.
It's for deterministic installs.
And that is important for your 2 user groups: end users of noVNC (i.e. people that use solutions based on noVNC) and developer of noVNC (people, like me, that contribute to the project and most likely building solutions for users using noVNC).

Your end users do deployments of (solutions that include) noVNC and they want to know what they are deploying.
They want to generate a BOM of their solution and check if there are known vulnerabilities.
E.g., A couple of years ago I used noVNC on a project while I was working in a highly regulated industry.
We build a no-VNC solution to manage testing environments. This solution included noVNC and it was mandatory to control the versions of all library and validate them (we couldn't even pull directly from npm). So, I ended up forking the project and having to spend the double effort to offer deterministic dependencies to the end user since the project itself doesn't.

I understand that Cendio as a company, sells its own noVNC-based solution to it's customers and that's your priority. That's totally fair and I totally support this. I'm sure that when you package your solution to deliver it, you know exactly which versions of dependencies are going in and do your security checks.
However, noVNC is an open-source projects, so you should keep in mind the end users that are not direct Cendio customers. I think that it's a responsible thing to make it as safe as posible for other consumers of noVNC as well as for the Cendio client.

Your developers, like me, download the repo and work on it locally.
Without having the concrete dependencies, thinks like what happen to me might happen.
E.g., Karma release version 7 which is incompatible with 6. All the sudden, I run an install and things don't work.
Until someone creates a PR fixing the config, the solution won't work unless you manually change the version back to 6.


> What we want here is a Karma which is new enough to support what we need. Which admittedly isn't '*'. But it also isn't '6.4.1'. It's rather '>= 5', or whatever version it is, that we are currently implicitly assuming. I have no objections to adding something like that. It would be similar to how we try to keep track of which browser versions we require.

If you see my example just above. I don't think that it's exactly like that.
You don't need an exact version. But you don't always need the latest.
Let me give you another example.
Karma 6.4.1 is found to have a severe vulnerability. You could simply set 6.4.0 and make sure that your users are safe (or dependabot might do it for you). However, if you simply use `latest`, this won't be the case.

> This is a problem caused by the lock file, so not a missing benefit. If we don't block updates, then we won't block security fixes.

Not really.
You might have a vulnerability present in all packages newer than 6.4.1 where the latest is 6.4.5.
While the team solves the issue, you might be able to simply use 6.4.0. However, if you simply get latests and the dependency team doesn't fix the issue for a while. You are stuck with the vulnerability.

Also, if I run `npm install` and get a specific version. Even if in the future I run it again, npm detects that there ir already a valid package in `node_modules` and doesn't update.

> It seems you can use tags, so I think what we want is

npm tags are tricky.
If a library with a latests 7.5.1 releases a vulnerability fix for it as 7.5.2 and then back-port the fix for version 6.8.2 so users of v6 can still get the fix in, the latest tag will point to 6.8.2 unless the maintainer manually changes it.
This is something that I have seen in a few cases.


Sorry for the very long response.
I just wanted to make it very clear that this is not about me having to manually update some dependencies.
It's about compliance and about making things easier for developers and end users that rely on noVNC.

issue.title: Lack of versioning on the dependencies causes trouble
issue.body: **Describe the bug** Lack of versioning on the dependencies: * makes downloads idempotent (2 downloads might not yield the same result) * makes imposible to run `npm audits` * doesn't let GitHub's dependabot automatically create a PR to update a version whenever a vulnerability is found This is a request to revert #1278 and reset specific versions in package.json and add a package-lock.json. I know that it adds a bit of a maintenance. But dependabot will take care of the crucial stuff, it's not so hard to every now and then do a general update of dependencies (in my own OSS packages I do so before cutting new releases) and it will provide great benefits. I'm happy to set all the latests versions and create the package-lock.json, and create a PR if it would be welcomed. **To Reproduce** Steps to reproduce the behavior on a MacBook with Node 18.0.0: 1. npm install 2. npm test **Expected behavior** The tests run successfully. Which only happens after manually reinstalling the latest Karma version. **Screenshots** When running `TEST_BROWSER_NAME=ChromeHeadless npm test` I get: When running `npm test` and opening the browser I get the same: **Client (please complete the following information):** - OS: MacOS - Browser: All browsers - Browser version: [e.g. 22] **Server (please complete the following information):** - noVNC version: latests - VNC server: not relevant - WebSocket proxy: not relevant

comment.body:
Hi Pierre,

>  Because I cannot reproduce it here

That's exactly the problem 😅
npm installs are not deterministic without a `package-lock.json`.
The install that I get, is not the same that I get and it's not the same that some other contributor or user might get.

Since npm 7 they went further and they are not only deterministic on the versions being installed but also on the directory structure (see [blog post](https://blog.npmjs.org/post/621733939456933888/npm-v7-series-why-keep-package-lockjson.html)).


> how it is related to the problem you are seeing.
What exactly is triggering those problems?

When I do a clean `npm install`, Karma resolves to an old version.
This is probably due to some internal dependency requiring that all version and noVNC requiring any (`*`) version.
So I get an old Karma version that doesn't work.

The solution is to run `npm install karma` after `npm install` which installs the latest version of Karma and solves the issue.


> And how would a package lock help?

A package lock will make installs deterministic and will indicate exactly which dependencies have been proven to work.
Everyone will get the exact same dependency tree and folder directory and there will never be an "it works in my machine" type of issue. Regardess of how uncommon this type of issue might be.

As additional benefits:

Having strict dependencies would allow contributors to run `npm audit` and identify vulnerabilities in the library and would allow that github dependabot automatically create PRs when vulnerabilities are found. Dependabot runs automatically in all GitHub public repos. See an [example](https://github.com/juanjoDiaz/serverless-plugin-warmup/pull/238) in one of my projects.

Having a package lock also would allow us to use `https://docs.npmjs.com/cli/v8/commands/npm-ci` which guarantees 100% that you get what the lock file says whereas npm install simple installs whatever is missing in the `node_modules` folder.

issue.title: Add automatic coverage results and badge using coveralls, codecov or similar
issue.body:
To continue with #13.

At the moment, the coverage badge is manually created and clicking it goes nowhere.
Instead we should send our coverage results to a service like coverall, codecov, etc. so the badge is automatically generated and when clicking you go to that platform to see a complete report.
You can look at the coverage badge on https://github.com/juanjoDiaz/serverless-plugin-warmup if you don't know what I mean.

I tried setting up coveralls since it's what I use in all my OSS projects but I found that phpunit doesn't support the LCOV reporting format. Based on https://github.com/sebastianbergmann/php-code-coverage/pull/869 and https://github.com/sebastianbergmann/php-code-coverage/issues/735 the project seems quite dead and support won't come any time soon. So we need to either find a way to convert php unit results to lcov or look at alternatives.

comment.body:
Codecov seems to support cobertura which is also supported by phpunit.

There might be newer and better solutions. This are just the ones that I know of 🙂

issue.title: Lack of versioning on the dependencies causes trouble
issue.body: **Describe the bug** Lack of versioning on the dependencies: * makes downloads idempotent (2 downloads might not yield the same result) * makes imposible to run `npm audits` * doesn't let GitHub's dependabot automatically create a PR to update a version whenever a vulnerability is found This is a request to revert #1278 and reset specific versions in package.json and add a package-lock.json. I know that it adds a bit of a maintenance. But dependabot will take care of the crucial stuff, it's not so hard to every now and then do a general update of dependencies (in my own OSS packages I do so before cutting new releases) and it will provide great benefits. I'm happy to set all the latests versions and create the package-lock.json, and create a PR if it would be welcomed. **To Reproduce** Steps to reproduce the behavior on a MacBook with Node 18.0.0: 1. npm install 2. npm test **Expected behavior** The tests run successfully. Which only happens after manually reinstalling the latest Karma version. **Screenshots** When running `TEST_BROWSER_NAME=ChromeHeadless npm test` I get: When running `npm test` and opening the browser I get the same: **Client (please complete the following information):** - OS: MacOS - Browser: All browsers - Browser version: [e.g. 22] **Server (please complete the following information):** - noVNC version: latests - VNC server: not relevant - WebSocket proxy: not relevant

issue.title: Add automatic clipboard support
issue.body:
This PR adds support for automatic copy-pasting.
So when you are focused on the canvas and paste text it's pasted in the server and when you copy something in the server it's automatically copied to your local keyboard.

I've seen #1301 and #1174. But this takes a very different approach since it adds support for copy-pasting to noVNC's core. And I think that it's quite cleaner.

I've tested it in Safari, Firefox, and Chrome.
Unfortunately, the Clipboard API is only supported by Chrome and the `paste` event is broken (see https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=634426).
So it just does nothing in Safari and Firefox, while in Chrome the copying of data works but not the pasting.

So, for now, this is not super useful but it should become better as browser support improves.

WDYT?

comment.body:
Indeed. Re-installing Karma manually re-installed the latest version and fixed the issue.
I'll open a separate issue about that.

issue.title: Client attribute mapper

labels.name: kind/feature
labels.description: Categorizes a PR related to a new feature

issue.body:
### Description

User attributes are a first class citizen.
They have their own tab on the user view of the admin portal and they have a mapper so they can be included in tokens.

Clients attributes are second class citizens.
They do NOT have their own tab and must be managed through the Admin API, and they can't be mapped to be included in tokens.

I propose to bring parity to these two.
It doesn't seem like this is a new idea. Someone already asked for this a few years ago: https://lists.jboss.org/pipermail/keycloak-user/2016-March/005447.html

### Discussion

_No response_

### Motivation

I own a public API and use Keycloack to provide authentication and authorization.
I register all consumers of my API as client with only service account enabled so they can get tokens and call my API.
I'm adding some metadata to each client to be included in the token so my API has more information.

Standard use case, just as you would do for a user, but a client.

### Details

_No response_

issue.title: Add support for organizations
issue.body:
As an organization manager, I would like to be able to control who can access my packages so I can give access to new employees and also remove leavers.

At the moment this has to be done package by package, which can get burdensome if your number of packages grows.

Ideally, there should be something like "organizations" where organizations admins can manage users belonging to the org. Similar to what GitHub, NPM, etc.. offer.

This would also be a great way to control vendor namespace ownership. The current approach of "if you are in a single repo, you have access to the whole namespace" is a bit flaky. What if you have an external contributing to a single package?

Something like SSO would be just awesome, but I consider that more of a paid enterprise feature.

According to [MDN](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Clipboard_API),  support should be now there for most mayor browsers.

issue.title: Path of .middleware folder when searching for modules is broken with default folderName in Serverless 3.0
issue.body:
The path of the .middleware folder using the default configuration is broken in serverless 3.0 + serverless-middleware 3.0.

```
Framework Core: 3.22.0 (local) 3.21.0 (global)
Plugin: 6.2.2
SDK: 4.3.2
```

Error: ``` Error: Cannot find module '/project-name/.build/.middleware/service-name-functionName'```

Serverless for some reason is assuming that the ```/.middleware/``` directory is located inside of ```/.build/.middleware/``` and that is not the default location of the folder.

The ```pathToRoot``` variable resolves to just ```..``` without a preceding slash, (```../```) and I thought that was the problem although manually altering the following did not fix it.  Although, it does print out the preceding slash in the logs and doesn't seem to hurt anything.  Not sure if *not* adding a preceding slash was intentional or not.

```const pathToRoot = path.relative(pathFolder, this.serviceDir);``` - original
```const pathToRoot = path.relative(pathFolder, this.serviceDir) + '/';``` - modified

If I find a fix, I'm happy to commit it but since you likely can pinpoint it faster, I'm posting this for visibility into the issue as well as for archival purposes.

comment.body:
Hi @bcrigler ,

Thanks for the deep research on the issue:

Can you create a repo so I can reproduce the issue? Then it will be a lot easier for me to fix it.

The **Transpilation Issue** is by design. This plugin glue together all the middlewares into a single handler in whatever your original language was. Then it's up to you to use a separate plugin to do the transpilation.

So, the problem I think is the order in which you are using the plugin.
Both the typescrypt and the middleware plugins mingle with paths and handlers, typescript creates `.build` and middleware creates `.middleware`, and that's probably causing the error.
Changing the order so the middleware plugin runs before the typescript plugin probably fixes the issue.

```yaml
plugins:
  - serverless-middleware
  - serverless-plugin-typescript
  - serverless-plugin-common-excludes
  - serverless-plugin-include-dependencies
  - serverless-offline
```

If it doesn't work, can you provide a sample project so I can reproduce the issue and work on it?
